display.value: Material Recording, Scheduling, Dispatching, and Distributing Workers

definition.value: This minor occupation group includes the following eight broad occupations: (1) 43-5010 Cargo and Freight Agents, (2) 43-5020 Couriers and Messengers, (3) 43-5030 Dispatchers, (4) 43-5040 Meter Readers, Utilities, (5) 43-5050 Postal Service Workers, (6) 43-5060 Production, Planning, and Expediting Clerks, (7) 43-5070 Shipping, Receiving, and Inventory Clerks, and (8) 43-5110 Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping

Expedite and route movement of incoming and outgoing cargo and freight shipments in airline, train, and trucking terminals and shipping docks. Take orders from customers and arrange pickup of freight and cargo for delivery to loading platform. Prepare and examine bills of lading to determine shipping charges and tariffs.

Expedite and route movement of incoming and outgoing cargo and freight shipments in airline, train, and trucking terminals and shipping docks. Take orders from customers and arrange pickup of freight and cargo for delivery to loading platform. Prepare and examine bills of lading to determine shipping charges and tariffs.

Pick up and deliver messages, documents, packages, and other items between offices or departments within an establishment or directly to other business concerns, traveling by foot, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, or public conveyance. Excludes “Light Truck Drivers” (53-3033).

Pick up and deliver messages, documents, packages, and other items between offices or departments within an establishment or directly to other business concerns, traveling by foot, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile, or public conveyance. Excludes “Light Truck Drivers” (53-3033).
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 43-5031 Public Safety Telecommunicators, and (2) 43-5032 Dispatchers, Except Police, Fire, and Ambulance

Operate telephone, radio, or other communication systems to receive and communicate requests for emergency assistance at 9-1-1 public safety answering points and emergency operations centers. Take information from the public and other sources regarding crimes, threats, disturbances, acts of terrorism, fires, medical emergencies, and other public safety matters. May coordinate and provide information to law enforcement and emergency response personnel. May access sensitive databases and other information sources as needed. May provide additional instructions to callers based on knowledge of and certification in law enforcement, fire, or emergency medical procedures.

display.value: Dispatchers, Except Police, Fire, and Ambulance

definition.value: Schedule and dispatch workers, work crews, equipment, or service vehicles for conveyance of materials, freight, or passengers, or for normal installation, service, or emergency repairs rendered outside the place of business. Duties may include using radio, telephone, or computer to transmit assignments and compiling statistics and reports on work progress.
Read meter and record consumption of electricity, gas, water, or steam.
Read meter and record consumption of electricity, gas, water, or steam.

This broad occupation includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 43-5051 Postal Service Clerks, (2) 43-5052 Postal Service Mail Carriers, and (3) 43-5053 Postal Service Mail Sorters, Processors, and Processing Machine Operators

Perform any combination of tasks in a United States Postal Service (USPS) post office, such as receive letters and parcels; sell postage and revenue stamps, postal cards, and stamped envelopes; fill out and sell money orders; place mail in pigeon holes of mail rack or in bags; and examine mail for correct postage. Includes postal service clerks employed by USPS contractors.
Sort and deliver mail for the United States Postal Service (USPS). Deliver mail on established route by vehicle or on foot. Includes postal service mail carriers employed by USPS contractors.

display.value: Postal Service Mail Sorters, Processors, and Processing Machine Operators

definition.value: Prepare incoming and outgoing mail for distribution for the United States Postal Service (USPS). Examine, sort, and route mail. Load, operate, and occasionally adjust and repair mail processing, sorting, and canceling machinery. Keep records of shipments, pouches, and sacks, and perform other duties related to mail handling within the postal service. Includes postal service mail sorters and processors employed by USPS contractors. Excludes “Postal Service Clerks” (43-5051) and “Postal Service Mail Carriers” (43-5052).

Coordinate and expedite the flow of work and materials within or between departments of an establishment according to production schedule. Duties include reviewing and distributing production, work, and shipment schedules; conferring with department supervisors to determine progress of work and completion dates; and compiling reports on progress of work, inventory levels, costs, and production problems. Excludes “Project Management Specialists” (13-1082) and “Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping” (43-5111).

Coordinate and expedite the flow of work and materials within or between departments of an establishment according to production schedule. Duties include reviewing and distributing production, work, and shipment schedules; conferring with department supervisors to determine progress of work and completion dates; and compiling reports on progress of work, inventory levels, costs, and production problems. Excludes “Project Management Specialists” (13-1082) and “Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping” (43-5111).

Verify and maintain records on incoming and outgoing shipments involving inventory. Duties include verifying and recording incoming merchandise or material and arranging for the transportation of products. May prepare items for shipment. Excludes “Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping” (43-5111), “Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, except Postal Service” (43-9051), and “Stockers and Order Fillers” (53-7065).

Verify and maintain records on incoming and outgoing shipments involving inventory. Duties include verifying and recording incoming merchandise or material and arranging for the transportation of products. May prepare items for shipment. Excludes “Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping” (43-5111), “Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, except Postal Service” (43-9051), and “Stockers and Order Fillers” (53-7065).

display.value: Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping

definition.value: Weigh, measure, and check materials, supplies, and equipment for the purpose of keeping relevant records. Duties are primarily clerical by nature. Includes workers who collect and keep record of samples of products or materials. Excludes “Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers” (51-9061).

display.value: Weighers, Measurers, Checkers, and Samplers, Recordkeeping

definition.value: Weigh, measure, and check materials, supplies, and equipment for the purpose of keeping relevant records. Duties are primarily clerical by nature. Includes workers who collect and keep record of samples of products or materials. Excludes “Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers” (51-9061).

This minor occupation group is the same as the broad occupation: 43-6010 Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, and includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 43-6011 Executive Secretaries and Executive Administrative Assistants, (2) 43-6012 Legal Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, (3) 43-6013 Medical Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, and (4) 43-6014 Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, Except Legal, Medical, and Executive

This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 43-6011 Executive Secretaries and Executive Administrative Assistants, (2) 43-6012 Legal Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, (3) 43-6013 Medical Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, and (4) 43-6014 Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, Except Legal, Medical, and Executive

display.value: Executive Secretaries and Executive Administrative Assistants

definition.value: Provide high-level administrative support by conducting research, preparing statistical reports, and handling information requests, as well as performing routine administrative functions such as preparing correspondence, receiving visitors, arranging conference calls, and scheduling meetings. May also train and supervise lower-level clerical staff. Excludes “Secretaries” (43-6012 through 43-6014).

Perform secretarial duties using legal terminology, procedures, and documents. Prepare legal papers and correspondence, such as summonses, complaints, motions, and subpoenas. May also assist with legal research.

Perform secretarial duties using specific knowledge of medical terminology and hospital, clinic, or laboratory procedures. Duties may include scheduling appointments, billing patients, and compiling and recording medical charts, reports, and correspondence.

display.value: Secretaries and Administrative Assistants, Except Legal, Medical, and Executive

definition.value: Perform routine administrative functions such as drafting correspondence, scheduling appointments, organizing and maintaining paper and electronic files, or providing information to callers. Excludes legal, medical, and executive secretaries (43-6011 through 43-6013).

display.value: Other Office and Administrative Support Workers

definition.value: This minor occupation group includes the following nine broad occupations: (1) 43-9020 Data Entry and Information Processing Workers, (2) 43-9030 Desktop Publishers, (3) 43-9040 Insurance Claims and Policy Processing Clerks, (4) 43-9050 Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service, (5) 43-9060 Office Clerks, General, (6) 43-9070 Office Machine Operators, Except Computer, (7) 43-9080 Proofreaders and Copy Markers, (8) 43-9110 Statistical Assistants, and (9) 43-9190 Miscellaneous Office and Administrative Support Workers

display.value: Data Entry and Information Processing Workers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 43-9021 Data Entry Keyers, and (2) 43-9022 Word Processors and Typists
Operate data entry device, such as keyboard or photo composing perforator. Duties may include verifying data and preparing materials for printing. Excludes “Word Processors and Typists” (43-9022).

Use word processor, computer, or typewriter to type letters, reports, forms, or other material from rough draft, corrected copy, or voice recording. May perform other clerical duties as assigned. Excludes “Court Reporters and Simultaneous Captioners” (27-3092), “Medical Transcriptionists” (31-9094), “Secretaries and Administrative Assistants” (43-6010), and “Data Entry Keyers” (43-9021).
Format typescript and graphic elements using computer software to produce publication-ready material.
Format typescript and graphic elements using computer software to produce publication-ready material.

display.value: Insurance Claims and Policy Processing Clerks

definition.value: Process new insurance policies, modifications to existing policies, and claims forms. Obtain information from policyholders to verify the accuracy and completeness of information on claims forms, applications and related documents, and company records. Update existing policies and company records to reflect changes requested by policyholders and insurance company representatives. Excludes “Claims Adjusters, Examiners, and Investigators” (13-1031).

display.value: Insurance Claims and Policy Processing Clerks

definition.value: Process new insurance policies, modifications to existing policies, and claims forms. Obtain information from policyholders to verify the accuracy and completeness of information on claims forms, applications and related documents, and company records. Update existing policies and company records to reflect changes requested by policyholders and insurance company representatives. Excludes “Claims Adjusters, Examiners, and Investigators” (13-1031).

display.value: Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service

definition.value: Prepare incoming and outgoing mail for distribution. Time-stamp, open, read, sort, and route incoming mail; and address, seal, stamp, fold, stuff, and affix postage to outgoing mail or packages. Duties may also include keeping necessary records and completed forms.

display.value: Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service

definition.value: Prepare incoming and outgoing mail for distribution. Time-stamp, open, read, sort, and route incoming mail; and address, seal, stamp, fold, stuff, and affix postage to outgoing mail or packages. Duties may also include keeping necessary records and completed forms.

Perform duties too varied and diverse to be classified in any specific office clerical occupation, requiring knowledge of office systems and procedures. Clerical duties may be assigned in accordance with the office procedures of individual establishments and may include a combination of answering telephones, bookkeeping, typing or word processing, office machine operation, and filing.

Perform duties too varied and diverse to be classified in any specific office clerical occupation, requiring knowledge of office systems and procedures. Clerical duties may be assigned in accordance with the office procedures of individual establishments and may include a combination of answering telephones, bookkeeping, typing or word processing, office machine operation, and filing.

Operate one or more of a variety of office machines, such as photocopying, photographic, and duplicating machines, or other office machines. Excludes “Billing and Posting Clerks” (43-3021) and “Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service” (43-9051).

Operate one or more of a variety of office machines, such as photocopying, photographic, and duplicating machines, or other office machines. Excludes “Billing and Posting Clerks” (43-3021) and “Mail Clerks and Mail Machine Operators, Except Postal Service” (43-9051).

Read transcript or proof type setup to detect and mark for correction any grammatical, typographical, or compositional errors. Excludes workers whose primary duty is editing copy. Includes proofreaders of braille.

Read transcript or proof type setup to detect and mark for correction any grammatical, typographical, or compositional errors. Excludes workers whose primary duty is editing copy. Includes proofreaders of braille.

Compile and compute data according to statistical formulas for use in statistical studies. May perform actuarial computations and compile charts and graphs for use by actuaries. Includes actuarial clerks.

Compile and compute data according to statistical formulas for use in statistical studies. May perform actuarial computations and compile charts and graphs for use by actuaries. Includes actuarial clerks.

display.value: Miscellaneous Office and Administrative Support Workers

definition.value: All office and administrative support workers not listed separately.

display.value: Office and Administrative Support Workers, All Other

definition.value: All office and administrative support workers not listed separately.

This major occupation group includes the following four minor occupation groups: (1) 45-1000 Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers, (2) 45-2000 Agricultural Workers, (3) 45-3000 Fishing and Hunting Workers, and (4) 45-4000 Forest, Conservation, and Logging Workers

display.value: Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers

definition.value: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of agricultural, forestry, aquacultural, and related workers. Excludes “First-Line Supervisors of Landscaping, Lawn Service, and Groundskeeping Workers” (37-1012).

display.value: First-Line Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers

definition.value: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of agricultural, forestry, aquacultural, and related workers. Excludes “First-Line Supervisors of Landscaping, Lawn Service, and Groundskeeping Workers” (37-1012).

display.value: First-Line Supervisors of Farming, Fishing, and Forestry Workers

definition.value: Directly supervise and coordinate the activities of agricultural, forestry, aquacultural, and related workers. Excludes “First-Line Supervisors of Landscaping, Lawn Service, and Groundskeeping Workers” (37-1012).

This minor occupation group includes the following four broad occupations: (1) 45-2010 Agricultural Inspectors, (2) 45-2020 Animal Breeders, (3) 45-2040 Graders and Sorters, Agricultural Products, and (4) 45-2090 Miscellaneous Agricultural Workers
Inspect agricultural commodities, processing equipment, and facilities, and fish and logging operations, to ensure compliance with regulations and laws governing health, quality, and safety.
Inspect agricultural commodities, processing equipment, and facilities, and fish and logging operations, to ensure compliance with regulations and laws governing health, quality, and safety.

Select and breed animals according to their genealogy, characteristics, and offspring. May require knowledge of artificial insemination techniques and equipment use. May involve keeping records on heats, birth intervals, or pedigree. Excludes “Animal Scientists” (19-1011) whose primary function is research and “Animal Caretakers” (39-2021) who may occasionally breed animals as part of their other caretaking duties.

Select and breed animals according to their genealogy, characteristics, and offspring. May require knowledge of artificial insemination techniques and equipment use. May involve keeping records on heats, birth intervals, or pedigree. Excludes “Animal Scientists” (19-1011) whose primary function is research and “Animal Caretakers” (39-2021) who may occasionally breed animals as part of their other caretaking duties.
Grade, sort, or classify unprocessed food and other agricultural products by size, weight, color, or condition. Excludes “Agricultural Inspectors” (45-2011).
Grade, sort, or classify unprocessed food and other agricultural products by size, weight, color, or condition. Excludes “Agricultural Inspectors” (45-2011).

This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 45-2091 Agricultural Equipment Operators, (2) 45-2092 Farmworkers and Laborers, Crop, Nursery, and Greenhouse, (3) 45-2093 Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals, and (4) 45-2099 Agricultural Workers, All Other

Drive and control equipment to support agricultural activities such as tilling soil; planting, cultivating, and harvesting crops; feeding and herding livestock; or removing animal waste. May perform tasks such as crop baling or hay bucking. May operate stationary equipment to perform post-harvest tasks such as husking, shelling, threshing, and ginning.

display.value: Farmworkers and Laborers, Crop, Nursery, and Greenhouse

definition.value: Manually plant, cultivate, and harvest vegetables, fruits, nuts, horticultural specialties, and field crops. Use hand tools, such as shovels, trowels, hoes, tampers, pruning hooks, shears, and knives. Duties may include tilling soil and applying fertilizers; transplanting, weeding, thinning, or pruning crops; applying pesticides; or cleaning, grading, sorting, packing, and loading harvested products. May construct trellises, repair fences and farm buildings, or participate in irrigation activities. Excludes “Pesticide Handlers, Sprayers, and Applicators, Vegetation” (37-3012), “Graders and Sorters, Agricultural Products” (45-2041), and “Forest, Conservation, and Logging Workers” (45-4011 through 45-4029).

display.value: Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals

definition.value: Attend to live farm, ranch, open range or aquacultural animals that may include cattle, sheep, swine, goats, horses and other equines, poultry, rabbits, finfish, shellfish, and bees. Attend to animals produced for animal products, such as meat, fur, skins, feathers, eggs, milk, and honey. Duties may include feeding, watering, herding, grazing, milking, castrating, branding, de-beaking, weighing, catching, and loading animals. May maintain records on animals; examine animals to detect diseases and injuries; assist in birth deliveries; and administer medications, vaccinations, or insecticides as appropriate. May clean and maintain animal housing areas. Includes workers who shear wool from sheep and collect eggs in hatcheries.
All agricultural workers not listed separately.

Hunt, trap, catch, or gather wild animals or aquatic animals and plants. May use nets, traps, or other equipment. May haul catch onto ship or other vessel. Aquacultural laborers who work on fish farms are included in “Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals” (45-2093).

Hunt, trap, catch, or gather wild animals or aquatic animals and plants. May use nets, traps, or other equipment. May haul catch onto ship or other vessel. Aquacultural laborers who work on fish farms are included in “Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals” (45-2093).

Hunt, trap, catch, or gather wild animals or aquatic animals and plants. May use nets, traps, or other equipment. May haul catch onto ship or other vessel. Aquacultural laborers who work on fish farms are included in “Farmworkers, Farm, Ranch, and Aquacultural Animals” (45-2093).
This minor occupation group includes the following two broad occupations: (1) 45-4010 Forest and Conservation Workers, and (2) 45-4020 Logging Workers

Under supervision, perform manual labor necessary to develop, maintain, or protect areas such as forests, forested areas, woodlands, wetlands, and rangelands through such activities as raising and transporting seedlings; combating insects, pests, and diseases harmful to plant life; and building structures to control water, erosion, and leaching of soil. Includes forester aides, seedling pullers, tree planters, and gatherers of nontimber forestry products such as pine straw.

Under supervision, perform manual labor necessary to develop, maintain, or protect areas such as forests, forested areas, woodlands, wetlands, and rangelands through such activities as raising and transporting seedlings; combating insects, pests, and diseases harmful to plant life; and building structures to control water, erosion, and leaching of soil. Includes forester aides, seedling pullers, tree planters, and gatherers of nontimber forestry products such as pine straw.

This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 45-4021 Fallers, (2) 45-4022 Logging Equipment Operators, (3) 45-4023 Log Graders and Scalers, and (4) 45-4029 Logging Workers, All Other
Use axes or chainsaws to fell trees using knowledge of tree characteristics and cutting techniques to control direction of fall and minimize tree damage.

Drive logging tractor or wheeled vehicle equipped with one or more accessories, such as bulldozer blade, frontal shear, grapple, logging arch, cable winches, hoisting rack, or crane boom, to fell tree; to skid, load, unload, or stack logs; or to pull stumps or clear brush. Includes operating stand-alone logging machines, such as log chippers. Logging truck drivers are included in “Heavy and Tractor-Trailer Truck Drivers” (53-3032).

Grade logs or estimate the marketable content or value of logs or pulpwood in sorting yards, millpond, log deck, or similar locations. Inspect logs for defects or measure logs to determine volume. Excludes “Buyers and Purchasing Agents, Farm Products” (13-1021).
All logging workers not listed separately.

This major occupation group includes the following five minor occupation groups: (1) 47-1000 Supervisors of Construction and Extraction Workers, (2) 47-2000 Construction Trades Workers, (3) 47-3000 Helpers, Construction Trades, (4) 47-4000 Other Construction and Related Workers, and (5) 47-5000 Extraction Workers

display.value: Supervisors of Construction and Extraction Workers

definition.value: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of construction or extraction workers.

display.value: First-Line Supervisors of Construction Trades and Extraction Workers

definition.value: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of construction or extraction workers.

display.value: First-Line Supervisors of Construction Trades and Extraction Workers

definition.value: Directly supervise and coordinate activities of construction or extraction workers.

This minor occupation group includes the following nineteen broad occupations: (1) 47-2010 Boilermakers, (2) 47-2020 Brickmasons, Blockmasons, and Stonemasons, (3) 47-2030 Carpenters, (4) 47-2040 Carpet, Floor, and Tile Installers and Finishers, (5) 47-2050 Cement Masons, Concrete Finishers, and Terrazzo Workers, (6) 47-2060 Construction Laborers, (7) 47-2070 Construction Equipment Operators, (8) 47-2080 Drywall Installers, Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers, (9) 47-2110 Electricians, (10) 47-2120 Glaziers, (11) 47-2130 Insulation Workers, (12) 47-2140 Painters and Paperhangers, (13) 47-2150 Pipelayers, Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters, (14) 47-2160 Plasterers and Stucco Masons, (15) 47-2170 Reinforcing Iron and Rebar Workers, (16) 47-2180 Roofers, (17) 47-2210 Sheet Metal Workers, (18) 47-2220 Structural Iron and Steel Workers, and (19) 47-2230 Solar Photovoltaic Installers

Construct, assemble, maintain, and repair stationary steam boilers and boiler house auxiliaries. Align structures or plate sections to assemble boiler frame tanks or vats, following blueprints. Work involves use of hand and power tools, plumb bobs, levels, wedges, dogs, or turnbuckles. Assist in testing assembled vessels. Direct cleaning of boilers and boiler furnaces. Inspect and repair boiler fittings, such as safety valves, regulators, automatic-control mechanisms, water columns, and auxiliary machines.

Construct, assemble, maintain, and repair stationary steam boilers and boiler house auxiliaries. Align structures or plate sections to assemble boiler frame tanks or vats, following blueprints. Work involves use of hand and power tools, plumb bobs, levels, wedges, dogs, or turnbuckles. Assist in testing assembled vessels. Direct cleaning of boilers and boiler furnaces. Inspect and repair boiler fittings, such as safety valves, regulators, automatic-control mechanisms, water columns, and auxiliary machines.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 47-2021 Brickmasons and Blockmasons, and (2) 47-2022 Stonemasons

Lay and bind building materials, such as brick, structural tile, concrete block, cinder block, glass block, and terra-cotta block, with mortar and other substances, to construct or repair walls, partitions, arches, sewers, and other structures. Installers of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units are classified in “Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers” (37-3011). Excludes “Stonemasons” (47-2022).
Build stone structures, such as piers, walls, and abutments. Lay walks, curbstones, or special types of masonry for vats, tanks, and floors.

Construct, erect, install, or repair structures and fixtures made of wood and comparable materials, such as concrete forms; building frameworks, including partitions, joists, studding, and rafters; and wood stairways, window and door frames, and hardwood floors. May also install cabinets, siding, drywall, and batt or roll insulation. Includes brattice builders who build doors or brattices (ventilation walls or partitions) in underground passageways.

Construct, erect, install, or repair structures and fixtures made of wood and comparable materials, such as concrete forms; building frameworks, including partitions, joists, studding, and rafters; and wood stairways, window and door frames, and hardwood floors. May also install cabinets, siding, drywall, and batt or roll insulation. Includes brattice builders who build doors or brattices (ventilation walls or partitions) in underground passageways.

display.value: Carpet, Floor, and Tile Installers and Finishers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 47-2041 Carpet Installers, (2) 47-2042 Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles, (3) 47-2043 Floor Sanders and Finishers, and (4) 47-2044 Tile and Stone Setters
Lay and install carpet from rolls or blocks on floors. Install padding and trim flooring materials. Excludes “Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles” (47-2042).

display.value: Floor Layers, Except Carpet, Wood, and Hard Tiles

definition.value: Apply blocks, strips, or sheets of shock-absorbing, sound-deadening, or decorative coverings to floors.
Scrape and sand wooden floors to smooth surfaces using floor scraper and floor sanding machine, and apply coats of finish.
Apply hard tile, stone, and comparable materials to walls, floors, ceilings, countertops, and roof decks.

display.value: Cement Masons, Concrete Finishers, and Terrazzo Workers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 47-2051 Cement Masons and Concrete Finishers, and (2) 47-2053 Terrazzo Workers and Finishers

Smooth and finish surfaces of poured concrete, such as floors, walks, sidewalks, roads, or curbs using a variety of hand and power tools. Align forms for sidewalks, curbs, or gutters; patch voids; and use saws to cut expansion joints. Installers of mortarless segmental concrete masonry wall units are classified in “Landscaping and Groundskeeping Workers” (37-3011).
Apply a mixture of cement, sand, pigment, or marble chips to floors, stairways, and cabinet fixtures to fashion durable and decorative surfaces.

Perform tasks involving physical labor at construction sites. May operate hand and power tools of all types: air hammers, earth tampers, cement mixers, small mechanical hoists, surveying and measuring equipment, and a variety of other equipment and instruments. May clean and prepare sites, dig trenches, set braces to support the sides of excavations, erect scaffolding, and clean up rubble, debris, and other waste materials. May assist other craft workers. Construction laborers who primarily assist a particular craft worker are classified under “Helpers, Construction Trades” (47-3010). Excludes “Hazardous Materials Removal Workers” (47-4041).

Perform tasks involving physical labor at construction sites. May operate hand and power tools of all types: air hammers, earth tampers, cement mixers, small mechanical hoists, surveying and measuring equipment, and a variety of other equipment and instruments. May clean and prepare sites, dig trenches, set braces to support the sides of excavations, erect scaffolding, and clean up rubble, debris, and other waste materials. May assist other craft workers. Construction laborers who primarily assist a particular craft worker are classified under “Helpers, Construction Trades” (47-3010). Excludes “Hazardous Materials Removal Workers” (47-4041).

This broad occupation includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 47-2071 Paving, Surfacing, and Tamping Equipment Operators, (2) 47-2072 Pile Driver Operators, and (3) 47-2073 Operating Engineers and Other Construction Equipment Operators

display.value: Paving, Surfacing, and Tamping Equipment Operators

definition.value: Operate equipment used for applying concrete, asphalt, or other materials to road beds, parking lots, or airport runways and taxiways or for tamping gravel, dirt, or other materials. Includes concrete and asphalt paving machine operators, form tampers, tamping machine operators, and stone spreader operators.

Operate pile drivers mounted on skids, barges, crawler treads, or locomotive cranes to drive pilings for retaining walls, bulkheads, and foundations of structures such as buildings, bridges, and piers.

display.value: Operating Engineers and Other Construction Equipment Operators

definition.value: Operate one or several types of power construction equipment, such as motor graders, bulldozers, scrapers, compressors, pumps, derricks, shovels, tractors, or front-end loaders to excavate, move, and grade earth, erect structures, or pour concrete or other hard surface pavement. May repair and maintain equipment in addition to other duties. Excludes “Extraction Workers” (47-5000) and “Crane and Tower Operators” (53-7021).

display.value: Drywall Installers, Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 47-2081 Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and (2) 47-2082 Tapers

Apply plasterboard or other wallboard to ceilings or interior walls of buildings. Apply or mount acoustical tiles or blocks, strips, or sheets of shock-absorbing materials to ceilings and walls of buildings to reduce or reflect sound. Materials may be of decorative quality. Includes lathers who fasten wooden, metal, or rockboard lath to walls, ceilings, or partitions of buildings to provide support base for plaster, fireproofing, or acoustical material. Excludes “Carpenters” (47-2031), “Carpet Installers” (47-2041), and “Tile and Stone Setters” (47-2044).
Seal joints between plasterboard or other wallboard to prepare wall surface for painting or papering.

Install, maintain, and repair electrical wiring, equipment, and fixtures. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes. May install or service street lights, intercom systems, or electrical control systems. Excludes “Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers” (49-2098).

Install, maintain, and repair electrical wiring, equipment, and fixtures. Ensure that work is in accordance with relevant codes. May install or service street lights, intercom systems, or electrical control systems. Excludes “Security and Fire Alarm Systems Installers” (49-2098).
Install glass in windows, skylights, store fronts, and display cases, or on surfaces, such as building fronts, interior walls, ceilings, and tabletops.
Install glass in windows, skylights, store fronts, and display cases, or on surfaces, such as building fronts, interior walls, ceilings, and tabletops.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 47-2131 Insulation Workers, Floor, Ceiling, and Wall, and (2) 47-2132 Insulation Workers, Mechanical

display.value: Insulation Workers, Floor, Ceiling, and Wall

definition.value: Line and cover structures with insulating materials. May work with batt, roll, or blown insulation materials.
Apply insulating materials to pipes or ductwork, or other mechanical systems in order to help control and maintain temperature.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 47-2141 Painters, Construction and Maintenance, and (2) 47-2142 Paperhangers

Paint walls, equipment, buildings, bridges, and other structural surfaces, using brushes, rollers, and spray guns. May remove old paint to prepare surface prior to painting. May mix colors or oils to obtain desired color or consistency. Excludes “Paperhangers” (47-2142).

Cover interior walls or ceilings of rooms with decorative wallpaper or fabric, or attach advertising posters on surfaces such as walls and billboards. May remove old materials or prepare surfaces to be papered.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 47-2151 Pipelayers, and (2) 47-2152 Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters

Lay pipe for storm or sanitation sewers, drains, and water mains. Perform any combination of the following tasks: grade trenches or culverts, position pipe, or seal joints. Excludes “Welders, Cutters, Solderers, and Brazers” (51-4121).

Assemble, install, alter, and repair pipelines or pipe systems that carry water, steam, air, or other liquids or gases. May install heating and cooling equipment and mechanical control systems. Includes sprinkler fitters.
Apply interior or exterior plaster, cement, stucco, or similar materials. May also set ornamental plaster.
Apply interior or exterior plaster, cement, stucco, or similar materials. May also set ornamental plaster.
Position and secure steel bars or mesh in concrete forms in order to reinforce concrete. Use a variety of fasteners, rod-bending machines, blowtorches, and hand tools. Includes rod busters.
Position and secure steel bars or mesh in concrete forms in order to reinforce concrete. Use a variety of fasteners, rod-bending machines, blowtorches, and hand tools. Includes rod busters.

Cover roofs of structures with shingles, slate, asphalt, aluminum, wood, or related materials. May spray roofs, sidings, and walls with material to bind, seal, insulate, or soundproof sections of structures.

Cover roofs of structures with shingles, slate, asphalt, aluminum, wood, or related materials. May spray roofs, sidings, and walls with material to bind, seal, insulate, or soundproof sections of structures.

Fabricate, assemble, install, and repair sheet metal products and equipment, such as ducts, control boxes, drainpipes, and furnace casings. Work may involve any of the following: setting up and operating fabricating machines to cut, bend, and straighten sheet metal; shaping metal over anvils, blocks, or forms using hammer; operating soldering and welding equipment to join sheet metal parts; or inspecting, assembling, and smoothing seams and joints of burred surfaces. Includes sheet metal duct installers who install prefabricated sheet metal ducts used for heating, air conditioning, or other purposes.

Fabricate, assemble, install, and repair sheet metal products and equipment, such as ducts, control boxes, drainpipes, and furnace casings. Work may involve any of the following: setting up and operating fabricating machines to cut, bend, and straighten sheet metal; shaping metal over anvils, blocks, or forms using hammer; operating soldering and welding equipment to join sheet metal parts; or inspecting, assembling, and smoothing seams and joints of burred surfaces. Includes sheet metal duct installers who install prefabricated sheet metal ducts used for heating, air conditioning, or other purposes.

Raise, place, and unite iron or steel girders, columns, and other structural members to form completed structures or structural frameworks. May erect metal storage tanks and assemble prefabricated metal buildings. Excludes “Reinforcing Iron and Rebar Workers” (47-2171).

Raise, place, and unite iron or steel girders, columns, and other structural members to form completed structures or structural frameworks. May erect metal storage tanks and assemble prefabricated metal buildings. Excludes “Reinforcing Iron and Rebar Workers” (47-2171).

Assemble, install, or maintain solar photovoltaic (PV) systems on roofs or other structures in compliance with site assessment and schematics. May include measuring, cutting, assembling, and bolting structural framing and solar modules. May perform minor electrical work such as current checks. Excludes solar PV electricians who are included in “Electricians” (47-2111) and solar thermal installers who are included in “Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters” (47-2152).

Assemble, install, or maintain solar photovoltaic (PV) systems on roofs or other structures in compliance with site assessment and schematics. May include measuring, cutting, assembling, and bolting structural framing and solar modules. May perform minor electrical work such as current checks. Excludes solar PV electricians who are included in “Electricians” (47-2111) and solar thermal installers who are included in “Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters” (47-2152).

This minor occupation group is the same as the broad occupation: 47-3010 Helpers, Construction Trades, and includes the following seven detailed occupations: (1) 47-3011 Helpers--Brickmasons, Blockmasons, Stonemasons, and Tile and Marble Setters, (2) 47-3012 Helpers--Carpenters, (3) 47-3013 Helpers--Electricians, (4) 47-3014 Helpers--Painters, Paperhangers, Plasterers, and Stucco Masons, (5) 47-3015 Helpers--Pipelayers, Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters, (6) 47-3016 Helpers--Roofers, and (7) 47-3019 Helpers, Construction Trades, All Other

This broad occupation includes the following seven detailed occupations: (1) 47-3011 Helpers--Brickmasons, Blockmasons, Stonemasons, and Tile and Marble Setters, (2) 47-3012 Helpers--Carpenters, (3) 47-3013 Helpers--Electricians, (4) 47-3014 Helpers--Painters, Paperhangers, Plasterers, and Stucco Masons, (5) 47-3015 Helpers--Pipelayers, Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters, (6) 47-3016 Helpers--Roofers, and (7) 47-3019 Helpers, Construction Trades, All Other

display.value: Helpers--Brickmasons, Blockmasons, Stonemasons, and Tile and Marble Setters

definition.value: Help brickmasons, blockmasons, stonemasons, or tile and marble setters by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist brickmasons, blockmasons, and stonemasons or tile and marble setters are classified under “Construction Laborers” (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help carpenters by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist carpenters are classified under “Construction Laborers” (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help electricians by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist electricians are classified under “Construction Laborers” (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

display.value: Helpers--Painters, Paperhangers, Plasterers, and Stucco Masons

definition.value: Help painters, paperhangers, plasterers, or stucco masons by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist painters, paperhangers, plasterers, or stucco masons are classified under “Construction Laborers” (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help plumbers, pipefitters, steamfitters, or pipelayers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist plumbers, pipefitters, steamfitters, or pipelayers are classified under “Construction Laborers” (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).

Help roofers by performing duties requiring less skill. Duties include using, supplying, or holding materials or tools, and cleaning work area and equipment. Construction laborers who do not primarily assist roofers are classified under “Construction Laborers” (47-2061). Apprentice workers are classified with the appropriate skilled construction trade occupation (47-2011 through 47-2231).
All construction trades helpers not listed separately.

This minor occupation group includes the following eight broad occupations: (1) 47-4010 Construction and Building Inspectors, (2) 47-4020 Elevator and Escalator Installers and Repairers, (3) 47-4030 Fence Erectors, (4) 47-4040 Hazardous Materials Removal Workers, (5) 47-4050 Highway Maintenance Workers, (6) 47-4060 Rail-Track Laying and Maintenance Equipment Operators, (7) 47-4070 Septic Tank Servicers and Sewer Pipe Cleaners, and (8) 47-4090 Miscellaneous Construction and Related Workers

Inspect structures using engineering skills to determine structural soundness and compliance with specifications, building codes, and other regulations. Inspections may be general in nature or may be limited to a specific area, such as electrical systems or plumbing.

Identify, remove, pack, transport, or dispose of hazardous materials, including asbestos, lead-based paint, waste oil, fuel, transmission fluid, radioactive materials, or contaminated soil. Specialized training and certification in hazardous materials handling or a confined entry permit are generally required. May operate earth-moving equipment or trucks.

Specialized training and certification in hazardous materials handling or a confined entry permit are generally required. May operate earth-moving equipment or trucks.

Maintain highways, municipal and rural roads, airport runways, and rights-of-way. Duties include patching broken or eroded pavement and repairing guard rails, highway markers, and snow fences. May also mow or clear brush from along road, or plow snow from roadway. Excludes “Tree Trimmers and Pruners” (37-3013).

Maintain highways, municipal and rural roads, airport runways, and rights-of-way. Duties include patching broken or eroded pavement and repairing guard rails, highway markers, and snow fences. May also mow or clear brush from along road, or plow snow from roadway. Excludes “Tree Trimmers and Pruners” (37-3013).

definition.value: Lay, repair, and maintain track for standard or narrow-gauge railroad equipment used in regular railroad service or in plant yards, quarries, sand and gravel pits, and mines. Includes ballast cleaning machine operators and railroad bed tamping machine operators.

This minor occupation group includes the following eight broad occupations: (1) 47-5010 Derrick, Rotary Drill, and Service Unit Operators, Oil and Gas, (2) 47-5020 Surface Mining Machine Operators and Earth Drillers, (3) 47-5030 Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters, (4) 47-5040 Underground Mining Machine Operators, (5) 47-5050 Rock Splitters, Quarry, (6) 47-5070 Roustabouts, Oil and Gas, (7) 47-5080 Helpers--Extraction Workers, and (8) 47-5090 Miscellaneous Extraction Workers

display.value: Service Unit Operators, Oil and Gas

definition.value: Operate equipment to increase oil flow from producing wells or to remove stuck pipe, casing, tools, or other obstructions from drilling wells. Includes fishing-tool technicians.

Includes horizontal and earth boring machine operators.

display.value: Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters

display.value: Explosives Workers, Ordnance Handling Experts, and Blasters

definition.value: Place and detonate explosives to demolish structures or to loosen, remove, or displace earth, rock, or other materials. May perform specialized handling, storage, and accounting procedures.

Operate self-propelled mining machines that rip coal, metal and nonmetal ores, rock, stone, or sand from the mine face and load it onto conveyors, shuttle cars, or trucks in a continuous operation.
Operate machinery to install roof support bolts in underground mine.

display.value: Loading and Moving Machine Operators, Underground Mining

definition.value: Operate underground loading or moving machine to load or move core, ore, or rock using shuttle or mine car or conveyors. Equipment may include power shovels, hoisting engines equipped with cable-drawn scraper or scoop, or machines equipped with gathering arms and conveyor.

display.value: Underground Mining Machine Operators, All Other

definition.value: All underground mining machine operators not listed separately.

Separate blocks of rough dimension stone from quarry mass using jackhammers, wedges, or chop saws.

Help extraction craft workers, such as earth drillers, blasters and explosives workers, derrick operators, and mining machine operators, by performing duties requiring less skill. display.value: Computer, Automated Teller, and Office Machine Repairers

Service or repair telephone, cable television, Internet, and other communications equipment on customers’ property. May install communications equipment or communications wiring in buildings. Excludes “Telecommunications Line Installers and Repairers” (49-9052).

Install, repair, or adjust audio or television receivers, stereo systems, camcorders, video systems, or other electronic entertainment equipment in homes or other venues. May perform routine maintenance. Excludes “Audio and Video Technicians” (27-4011).

Diagnose, adjust, repair, or overhaul aircraft engines and assemblies, such as hydraulic and pneumatic systems. Excludes “Avionics Technicians” (49-2091).

May specialize in maintaining gas, electrical, hydraulic, plumbing, or chassis/towing systems as well as repairing generators, appliances, and interior components. Includes workers who perform customized van conversions. Excludes “Automotive Service Technicians and Mechanics” (49-3023) and “Bus and Truck Mechanics and Diesel Engine Specialists” (49-3031) who also work on recreation vehicles.
Repair and replace tires.

Duties may involve pipe fitting; HVAC maintenance; insulating; welding; machining; carpentry; repairing electrical or mechanical equipment; installing, aligning, and balancing new equipment; and repairing buildings, floors, or stairs. Excludes “Facilities Managers” (11-3013) and “Maintenance Workers, Machinery” (49-9043).

Perform work involving the skills of two or more maintenance or craft occupations to keep machines, mechanical equipment, or the structure of a building in repair. Repair and open locks, make keys, change locks and safe combinations, and install and repair safes.

display.value: Installation, Maintenance, and Repair Workers, All Other

definition.value: Assemble, fit, fasten, and install parts of airplanes, space vehicles, or missiles, such as tails, wings, fuselage, bulkheads, stabilizers, landing gear, rigging and control equipment, or heating and ventilating systems.

Construct, assemble, or rebuild machines, such as engines, turbines, and similar equipment used in such industries as construction, extraction, textiles, and paper manufacturing.
Fabricate, position, align, and fit parts of structural metal products. Shipfitters are included in “Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic” (51-4192).
Fabricate, position, align, and fit parts of structural metal products. Shipfitters are included in “Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic” (51-4192).
Laminate layers of fiberglass on molds to form boat decks and hulls, bodies for golf carts, automobiles, or other products.
Laminate layers of fiberglass on molds to form boat decks and hulls, bodies for golf carts, automobiles, or other products.

Perform precision assembling or adjusting, within narrow tolerances, of timing devices such as digital clocks or timing devices with electrical or electronic components. Watchmakers are included in “Watch and Clock Repairers” (49-9064).

Perform precision assembling or adjusting, within narrow tolerances, of timing devices such as digital clocks or timing devices with electrical or electronic components. Watchmakers are included in “Watch and Clock Repairers” (49-9064).
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-2092 Team Assemblers, and (2) 51-2099 Assemblers and Fabricators, All Other

Work as part of a team having responsibility for assembling an entire product or component of a product. Team assemblers can perform all tasks conducted by the team in the assembly process and rotate through all or most of them, rather than being assigned to a specific task on a permanent basis. May participate in making management decisions affecting the work. Includes team leaders who work as part of the team. Assemblers who continuously perform the same task are classified elsewhere in 51-2000.
All assemblers and fabricators not listed separately.

This minor occupation group includes the following three broad occupations: (1) 51-3010 Bakers, (2) 51-3020 Butchers and Other Meat, Poultry, and Fish Processing Workers, and (3) 51-3090 Miscellaneous Food Processing Workers
Mix and bake ingredients to produce breads, rolls, cookies, cakes, pies, pastries, or other baked goods. Pastry chefs in restaurants and hotels are included with “Chefs and Head Cooks” (35-1011).
Mix and bake ingredients to produce breads, rolls, cookies, cakes, pies, pastries, or other baked goods. Pastry chefs in restaurants and hotels are included with “Chefs and Head Cooks” (35-1011).

display.value: Butchers and Other Meat, Poultry, and Fish Processing Workers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 51-3021 Butchers and Meat Cutters, (2) 51-3022 Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers, and (3) 51-3023 Slaughterers and Meat Packers
Cut, trim, or prepare consumer-sized portions of meat for use or sale in retail establishments.

display.value: Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers

definition.value: Use hands or hand tools to perform routine cutting and trimming of meat, poultry, and seafood.

Perform nonroutine or precision functions involving the preparation of large portions of meat. Work may include specialized slaughtering tasks, cutting standard or premium cuts of meat for marketing, making sausage, or wrapping meats. Work typically occurs in slaughtering, meat packing, or wholesale establishments. Excludes “Meat, Poultry, and Fish Cutters and Trimmers” (51-3022) who perform routine meat cutting.

This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 51-3091 Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders, (2) 51-3092 Food Batchmakers, (3) 51-3093 Food Cooking Machine Operators and Tenders, and (4) 51-3099 Food Processing Workers, All Other

display.value: Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders

definition.value: Operate or tend food or tobacco roasting, baking, or drying equipment, including hearth ovens, kiln driers, roasters, char kilns, and vacuum drying equipment.
Set up and operate equipment that mixes or blends ingredients used in the manufacturing of food products. Includes candy makers and cheese makers.

display.value: Food Cooking Machine Operators and Tenders

definition.value: Operate or tend cooking equipment, such as steam cooking vats, deep fry cookers, pressure cookers, kettles, and boilers, to prepare food products. Excludes “Food and Tobacco Roasting, Baking, and Drying Machine Operators and Tenders” (51-3091).
All food processing workers not listed separately

This minor occupation group includes the following ten broad occupations: (1) 51-4020 Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (2) 51-4030 Machine Tool Cutting Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (3) 51-4040 Machinists, (4) 51-4050 Metal Furnace Operators, Tenders, Pourers, and Casters, (5) 51-4060 Model Makers and Patternmakers, Metal and Plastic, (6) 51-4070 Molders and Molding Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (7) 51-4080 Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (8) 51-4110 Tool and Die Makers, (9) 51-4120 Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Workers, and (10) 51-4190 Miscellaneous Metal Workers and Plastic Workers

display.value: Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 51-4021 Extruding and Drawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (2) 51-4022 Forging Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, and (3) 51-4023 Rolling Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

display.value: Extruding and Drawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines to extrude or draw thermoplastic or metal materials into tubes, rods, hoses, wire, bars, or structural shapes.

display.value: Forging Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend forging machines to taper, shape, or form metal or plastic parts.

display.value: Rolling Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines to roll steel or plastic forming bends, beads, knurls, rolls, or plate, or to flatten, temper, or reduce gauge of material.

display.value: Machine Tool Cutting Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following five detailed occupations: (1) 51-4031 Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (2) 51-4032 Drilling and Boring Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (3) 51-4033 Grinding, Lapping, Polishing, and Buffing Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (4) 51-4034 Lathe and Turning Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, and (5) 51-4035 Milling and Planing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

display.value: Cutting, Punching, and Press Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines to saw, cut, shear, slit, punch, crimp, notch, bend, or straighten metal or plastic material.

display.value: Drilling and Boring Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend drilling machines to drill, bore, ream, mill, or countersink metal or plastic work pieces.

display.value: Grinding, Lapping, Polishing, and Buffing Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend grinding and related tools that remove excess material or burrs from surfaces, sharpen edges or corners, or buff, hone, or polish metal or plastic work pieces.

display.value: Lathe and Turning Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend lathe and turning machines to turn, bore, thread, form, or face metal or plastic materials, such as wire, rod, or bar stock.

display.value: Milling and Planing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend milling or planing machines to mill, plane, shape, groove, or profile metal or plastic work pieces.

Set up and operate a variety of machine tools to produce precision parts and instruments out of metal. Includes precision instrument makers who fabricate, modify, or repair mechanical instruments. May also fabricate and modify parts to make or repair machine tools or maintain industrial machines, applying knowledge of mechanics, mathematics, metal properties, layout, and machining procedures. Machinists who primarily program or operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment are classified in “Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers” (51-9160).

Set up and operate a variety of machine tools to produce precision parts and instruments out of metal. Includes precision instrument makers who fabricate, modify, or repair mechanical instruments. May also fabricate and modify parts to make or repair machine tools or maintain industrial machines, applying knowledge of mechanics, mathematics, metal properties, layout, and machining procedures. Machinists who primarily program or operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment are classified in “Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers” (51-9160).

display.value: Metal Furnace Operators, Tenders, Pourers, and Casters

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-4051 Metal-Refining Furnace Operators and Tenders, and (2) 51-4052 Pourers and Casters, Metal

Operate or tend furnaces, such as gas, oil, coal, electric-arc or electric induction, open-hearth, or oxygen furnaces, to melt and refine metal before casting or to produce specified types of steel. Excludes “Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic” (51-4191).
Operate hand-controlled mechanisms to pour and regulate the flow of molten metal into molds to produce castings or ingots.

display.value: Model Makers and Patternmakers, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-4061 Model Makers, Metal and Plastic, and (2) 51-4062 Patternmakers, Metal and Plastic
Set up and operate machines, such as lathes, milling and engraving machines, and jig borers to make working models of metal or plastic objects. Includes template makers.
Lay out, machine, fit, and assemble castings and parts to metal or plastic foundry patterns, core boxes, or match plates.

display.value: Molders and Molding Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-4071 Foundry Mold and Coremakers, and (2) 51-4072 Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

Make or form wax or sand cores or molds used in the production of metal castings in foundries. Excludes “Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic” (51-4072) and “Molders, Shapers, and Casters, Except Metal and Plastic” (51-9195).

display.value: Molding, Coremaking, and Casting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend metal or plastic molding, casting, or coremaking machines to mold or cast metal or thermoplastic parts or products.

display.value: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend more than one type of cutting or forming machine tool or robot.

display.value: Multiple Machine Tool Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend more than one type of cutting or forming machine tool or robot.
Analyze specifications, lay out metal stock, set up and operate machine tools, and fit and assemble parts to make and repair dies, cutting tools, jigs, fixtures, gauges, and machinists’ hand tools.
Analyze specifications, lay out metal stock, set up and operate machine tools, and fit and assemble parts to make and repair dies, cutting tools, jigs, fixtures, gauges, and machinists’ hand tools.

This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-4121 Welders, Cutters, Solderers, and Brazers, and (2) 51-4122 Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
Use hand-welding, flame-cutting, hand-soldering, or brazing equipment to weld or join metal components or to fill holes, indentations, or seams of fabricated metal products.

display.value: Welding, Soldering, and Brazing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend welding, soldering, or brazing machines or robots that weld, braze, solder, or heat treat metal products, components, or assemblies. Includes workers who operate laser cutters or laser-beam machines.

display.value: Miscellaneous Metal Workers and Plastic Workers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following five detailed occupations: (1) 51-4191 Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (2) 51-4192 Layout Workers, Metal and Plastic, (3) 51-4193 Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic, (4) 51-4194 Tool Grinders, Filers, and Sharpeners, and (5) 51-4199 Metal Workers and Plastic Workers, All Other

display.value: Heat Treating Equipment Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend heating equipment, such as heat-treating furnaces, flame-hardening machines, induction machines, soaking pits, or vacuum equipment to temper, harden, anneal, or heat treat metal or plastic objects.

Lay out reference points and dimensions on metal or plastic stock or workpieces, such as sheets, plates, tubes, structural shapes, castings, or machine parts, for further processing. Includes shipfitters.

display.value: Plating Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Metal and Plastic

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend plating machines to coat metal or plastic products with chromium, zinc, copper, cadmium, nickel, or other metal to protect or decorate surfaces. Typically, the product being coated is immersed in molten metal or an electrolytic solution. Excludes “Coating, Painting, and Spraying Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders” (51-9124).
Perform precision smoothing, sharpening, polishing, or grinding of metal objects.

display.value: Metal Workers and Plastic Workers, All Other

definition.value: All metal workers and plastic workers not listed separately.

This minor occupation group is the same as the broad occupation: 51-5110 Printing Workers, and includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 51-5111 Prepress Technicians and Workers, (2) 51-5112 Printing Press Operators, and (3) 51-5113 Print Binding and Finishing Workers

This broad occupation includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 51-5111 Prepress Technicians and Workers, (2) 51-5112 Printing Press Operators, and (3) 51-5113 Print Binding and Finishing Workers
Format and proof text and images submitted by designers and clients into finished pages that can be printed. Includes digital and photo typesetting. May produce printing plates.
Set up and operate digital, letterpress, lithographic, flexographic, gravure, or other printing machines. Includes short-run offset printing presses.
Bind books and other publications or finish printed products by hand or machine. May set up binding and finishing machines.

This minor occupation group includes the following seven broad occupations: (1) 51-6010 Laundry and Dry-Cleaning Workers, (2) 51-6020 Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials, (3) 51-6030 Sewing Machine Operators, (4) 51-6040 Shoe and Leather Workers, (5) 51-6050 Tailors, Dressmakers, and Sewers, (6) 51-6060 Textile Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, and (7) 51-6090 Miscellaneous Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers

Operate or tend washing or dry-cleaning machines to wash or dry-clean industrial or household articles, such as cloth garments, suede, leather, furs, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets. Includes spotters and dyers of these articles.

Operate or tend washing or dry-cleaning machines to wash or dry-clean industrial or household articles, such as cloth garments, suede, leather, furs, blankets, draperies, linens, rugs, and carpets. Includes spotters and dyers of these articles.

display.value: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials

definition.value: Press or shape articles by hand or machine.

display.value: Pressers, Textile, Garment, and Related Materials

definition.value: Press or shape articles by hand or machine.
Operate or tend sewing machines to join, reinforce, decorate, or perform related sewing operations in the manufacture of garment or nongarment products.
Operate or tend sewing machines to join, reinforce, decorate, or perform related sewing operations in the manufacture of garment or nongarment products.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-6041 Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers, and (2) 51-6042 Shoe Machine Operators and Tenders

display.value: Shoe and Leather Workers and Repairers

definition.value: Construct, decorate, or repair leather and leather-like products, such as luggage, shoes, and saddles. May use hand tools.
Operate or tend a variety of machines to join, decorate, reinforce, or finish shoes and shoe parts.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-6051 Sewers, Hand, and (2) 51-6052 Tailors, Dressmakers, and Custom Sewers
Sew, join, reinforce, or finish, usually with needle and thread, a variety of manufactured items. Includes weavers and stitchers.
Design, make, alter, repair, or fit garments.

display.value: Textile Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 51-6061 Textile Bleaching and Dyeing Machine Operators and Tenders, (2) 51-6062 Textile Cutting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, (3) 51-6063 Textile Knitting and Weaving Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, and (4) 51-6064 Textile Winding, Twisting, and Drawing Out Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

display.value: Textile Bleaching and Dyeing Machine Operators and Tenders

definition.value: Operate or tend machines to bleach, shrink, wash, dye, or finish textiles or synthetic or glass fibers.

display.value: Textile Cutting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines that cut textiles.

display.value: Textile Knitting and Weaving Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines that knit, loop, weave, or draw in textiles. Excludes “Sewing Machine Operators” (51-6031).

display.value: Textile Winding, Twisting, and Drawing Out Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines that wind or twist textiles; or draw out and combine sliver, such as wool, hemp, or synthetic fibers. Includes slubber machine and drawing frame operators.

display.value: Miscellaneous Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 51-6091 Extruding and Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Synthetic and Glass Fibers, (2) 51-6092 Fabric and Apparel Patternmakers, (3) 51-6093 Upholsterers, and (4) 51-6099 Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers, All Other

display.value: Extruding and Forming Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Synthetic and Glass Fibers

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines that extrude and form continuous filaments from synthetic materials, such as liquid polymer, rayon, and fiberglass.
Draw and construct sets of precision master fabric patterns or layouts. May also mark and cut fabrics and apparel.
Make, repair, or replace upholstery for household furniture or transportation vehicles.

display.value: Textile, Apparel, and Furnishings Workers, All Other

definition.value: All textile, apparel, and furnishings workers not listed separately.

This minor occupation group includes the following five broad occupations: (1) 51-7010 Cabinetmakers and Bench Carpenters, (2) 51-7020 Furniture Finishers, (3) 51-7030 Model Makers and Patternmakers, Wood, (4) 51-7040 Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, and (5) 51-7090 Miscellaneous Woodworkers

Cut, shape, and assemble wooden articles or set up and operate a variety of woodworking machines, such as power saws, jointers, and mortisers to surface, cut, or shape lumber or to fabricate parts for wood products. Excludes “Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders” (51-7040).

Cut, shape, and assemble wooden articles or set up and operate a variety of woodworking machines, such as power saws, jointers, and mortisers to surface, cut, or shape lumber or to fabricate parts for wood products. Excludes “Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders” (51-7040).
Shape, finish, and refinish damaged, worn, or used furniture or new high-grade furniture to specified color or finish.
Shape, finish, and refinish damaged, worn, or used furniture or new high-grade furniture to specified color or finish.
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-7031 Model Makers, Wood, and (2) 51-7032 Patternmakers, Wood
Construct full-size and scale wooden precision models of products. Includes wood jig builders and loft workers.
Plan, lay out, and construct wooden unit or sectional patterns used in forming sand molds for castings.

display.value: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-7041 Sawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Wood, and (2) 51-7042 Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Except Sawing

display.value: Sawing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Wood

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend wood sawing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Includes lead sawyers. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in “Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers” (51-9160).

display.value: Woodworking Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, Except Sawing

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend woodworking machines, such as drill presses, lathes, shapers, routers, sanders, planers, and wood nailing machines. May operate computer numerically controlled (CNC) equipment. Workers who primarily program or operate CNC equipment are classified in “Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers” (51-9160).
All woodworkers not listed separately.
All woodworkers not listed separately.

This minor occupation group includes the following four broad occupations: (1) 51-8010 Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers, (2) 51-8020 Stationary Engineers and Boiler Operators, (3) 51-8030 Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators, and (4) 51-8090 Miscellaneous Plant and System Operators

display.value: Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following three detailed occupations: (1) 51-8011 Nuclear Power Reactor Operators, (2) 51-8012 Power Distributors and Dispatchers, and (3) 51-8013 Power Plant Operators

Operate or control nuclear reactors. Move control rods, start and stop equipment, monitor and adjust controls, and record data in logs. Implement emergency procedures when needed. May respond to abnormalities, determine cause, and recommend corrective action.
Coordinate, regulate, or distribute electricity or steam.
Control, operate, or maintain machinery to generate electric power. Includes auxiliary equipment operators. Excludes “Nuclear Power Reactor Operators” (51-8011).

Operate or maintain stationary engines, boilers, or other mechanical equipment to provide utilities for buildings or industrial processes. Operate equipment such as steam engines, generators, motors, turbines, and steam boilers.

Operate or maintain stationary engines, boilers, or other mechanical equipment to provide utilities for buildings or industrial processes. Operate equipment such as steam engines, generators, motors, turbines, and steam boilers.

display.value: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators

definition.value: Operate or control an entire process or system of machines, often through the use of control boards, to transfer or treat water or wastewater.

display.value: Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators

definition.value: Operate or control an entire process or system of machines, often through the use of control boards, to transfer or treat water or wastewater.

This broad occupation includes the following four detailed occupations: (1) 51-8091 Chemical Plant and System Operators, (2) 51-8092 Gas Plant Operators, (3) 51-8093 Petroleum Pump System Operators, Refinery Operators, and Gaugers, and (4) 51-8099 Plant and System Operators, All Other
Control or operate entire chemical processes or system of machines.
Distribute or process gas for utility companies and others by controlling compressors to maintain specified pressures on main pipelines.

display.value: Petroleum Pump System Operators, Refinery Operators, and Gaugers

definition.value: Operate or control petroleum refining or processing units. May specialize in controlling manifold and pumping systems, gauging or testing oil in storage tanks, or regulating the flow of oil into pipelines.

display.value: Plant and System Operators, All Other

definition.value: All plant and system operators not listed separately.

This minor occupation group includes the following fourteen broad occupations: (1) 51-9010 Chemical Processing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, (2) 51-9020 Crushing, Grinding, Polishing, Mixing, and Blending Workers, (3) 51-9030 Cutting Workers, (4) 51-9040 Extruding, Forming, Pressing, and Compacting Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders, (5) 51-9050 Furnace, Kiln, Oven, Drier, and Kettle Operators and Tenders, (6) 51-9060 Inspectors, Testers, Sorters, Samplers, and Weighers, (7) 51-9070 Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers, (8) 51-9080 Dental and Ophthalmic Laboratory Technicians and Medical Appliance Technicians, (9) 51-9110 Packaging and Filling Machine Operators and Tenders, (10) 51-9120 Painting Workers, (11) 51-9140 Semiconductor Processing Technicians, (12) 51-9150 Photographic Process Workers and Processing Machine Operators, (13) 51-9160 Computer Numerically Controlled Tool Operators and Programmers, and (14) 51-9190 Miscellaneous Production Workers

display.value: Chemical Processing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-9011 Chemical Equipment Operators and Tenders, and (2) 51-9012 Separating, Filtering, Clarifying, Precipitating, and Still Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

Operate or tend equipment to control chemical changes or reactions in the processing of industrial or consumer products. Equipment used includes devulcanizers, steam-jacketed kettles, and reactor vessels. Excludes “Chemical Plant and System Operators” (51-8091).

display.value: Separating, Filtering, Clarifying, Precipitating, and Still Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend continuous flow or vat-type equipment; filter presses; shaker screens; centrifuges; condenser tubes; precipitating, fermenting, or evaporating tanks; scrubbing towers; or batch stills. These machines extract, sort, or separate liquids, gases, or solids from other materials to recover a refined product. Includes dairy processing equipment operators. Excludes “Chemical Equipment Operators and Tenders” (51-9011).

display.value: Crushing, Grinding, and Polishing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines to crush, grind, or polish materials, such as coal, glass, grain, stone, food, or rubber.
Grind, sand, or polish, using hand tools or hand-held power tools, a variety of metal, wood, stone, clay, plastic, or glass objects. Includes chippers, buffers, and finishers.

display.value: Mixing and Blending Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders

definition.value: Set up, operate, or tend machines to mix or blend materials, such as chemicals, tobacco, liquids, color pigments, or explosive ingredients. Excludes “Food Batchmakers” (51-3092).
This broad occupation includes the following two detailed occupations: (1) 51-9031 Cutters and Trimmers, Hand, and (2) 51-9032 Cutting and Slicing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
Use hand tools or hand-held power tools to cut and trim a variety of manufactured items, such as carpet, fabric, stone, glass, or rubber.

display.value: Cutting and Slicing Machine Setters, Operators, and Tenders
